title: Mathematical Foundations and Practical Applications for Image Super-Resolution Restoration

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational mathematics (calculus, linear algebra) and basic understanding of image processing
context.additional_context: A practical mathematics application training program for corporate managers/leaders, utilizing smartphone-based supplementary learning materials in limited-technology environments.

learning_goals: At the end of the 6-month course, learners can apply mathematical modeling (e.g., Fourier transform, matrix decomposition) to ten different low-resolution image datasets and define super-resolution restoration problems using three or more mathematical techniques (e.g., CNN-based optimization, sparse coding).
They can explain the principles and applications of sparse prior-based restoration algorithms.

By the end of the 6-month course, learners will design two super-resolution solutions using real industrial data (10+ sets of infrared/multispectral images) and produce an evaluation report meeting performance criteria of PSNR (Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio) ≥ 30dB and SSIM (Structural Similarity) ≥ 0.90.

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
